title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of the total number of complaints received for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. Victim's information was misused for credit card fraud (25%), phone/utilities fraud (16%), bank fraud (16%), employment-related fraud (14%), and government documents/benefits fraud (5%). Identity theft complaints include bank fraud (16%), employment-related fraud (14%), government documents or benefits fraud (5%), loan fraud (5%), and other types of fraud (24%). Victims may suffer damaged credit records, unauthorized credit card charges, unauthorized bank withdrawals, and may need to change phone numbers, social security numbers, and addresses. With increasing media reports of data security breaches, concerns about new cases are rising. The report provides an overview of federal laws to assist identity theft victims in removing inaccurate information from credit records and unauthorized charges from credit accounts. It also addresses criminal penalties for those who assume another person's identity using fraudulent documents. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act is mentioned, although not exclusively focused on consumer identity theft. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud with identification documents, including producing or possessing false identification documents. Certain offenses under the statute relate to consumer identity theft, allowing impostors to be prosecuted. It is a federal crime to produce, possess, or transfer false identification documents or stolen identification documents of the United States. Punishment for fraud related to identification documents varies depending on the offense. The punishment for offenses involving fraud related to identification documents varies depending on the specific offense and the type of document involved. Penalties can include fines, imprisonment up to 15 years for certain offenses, and up to three years for others. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed in 2004, amends Title 18 of the United States Code to define and establish penalties for aggravated identity theft. Offenses related to drug trafficking or violence can result in up to twenty years of imprisonment, while those connected to international terrorism can lead to up to twenty-five years of imprisonment. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 defines penalties for aggravated identity theft, including a two-year imprisonment term for using another person's identification during certain felonies. Terrorism-related offenses can result in an additional five-year imprisonment. The act also requires the United States Sentencing Commission to review and amend its guidelines. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 increases penalties for identity theft, including a two-year imprisonment term for using another person's identification during certain felonies. Terrorism-related offenses can lead to an additional five-year imprisonment. The act also directs the United States Sentencing Commission to review and amend its guidelines to appropriately punish identity theft offenses involving an abuse of position. Additionally, the act authorizes appropriations to the Justice Department for the investigation and prosecution of identity theft and related fraud cases. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) does not directly address identity theft but could assist victims in removing negative information from their credit files. $2,000,000 is allocated for the investigation and prosecution of identity theft and fraud cases for FY2005 and the following 4 fiscal years. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) protects consumer rights regarding credit reports, ensuring accuracy and proper use of information. Consumers can take legal action for violations, including improper disclosure of information. The FCRA allows consumers to sue for violations, such as inaccurate information disclosed by credit reporting agencies. Victims of identity theft can also take legal action for agencies failing to verify information accurately. Consumers have up to two years after discovering a violation to file a lawsuit under the FCRA. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, amended the FCRA to allow consumers to file suit within two years of discovering a violation or five years of the violation occurring. This includes provisions to prevent identity theft and create a national standard for addressing consumer concerns. Credit card issuers are required to comply with these new provisions. Consumer concerns about identity theft and fraud are addressed by new provisions in the FCRA. Credit card issuers must follow specific procedures when a request for a new card is made shortly after a change of address. To prevent identity theft, credit card numbers on receipts are truncated, and social security numbers can be truncated on credit reports upon request by consumers who are victims or anticipate becoming victims of identity theft. The FCRA includes new provisions to address consumer concerns about identity theft and fraud. Consumers can request the truncation of social security numbers on credit reports and have fraud alerts placed in their files. Fraud alerts can be maintained for 90 days or extended up to seven years, and are passed along to all users of the credit report. Consumer can request an extended fraud alert for up to seven years, which becomes part of their credit file and is shared with all users of the report. Victims of identity theft can also have fraudulent information blocked from their credit reports with appropriate proof and an identity theft report. Upon request, victims of identity theft can have fraudulent information blocked from their credit reports by providing an identity theft report and relevant details to consumer reporting agencies. Additionally, victims can request information about the alleged crime from businesses upon verification of their identity. Business entities must provide victims of identity theft with copies of application and transaction records upon request and verification of identity. The Fair Credit Billing Act allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges made by impostors. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges, receive explanations, and have charges removed from their accounts. It aims to protect consumers from inaccurate credit billing practices by defining billing errors and establishing procedures for resolving them. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute billing errors and request written proof of purchase. Consumers can file a claim with the creditor to resolve the error, and until it is resolved, they are not required to pay the disputed amount. If the creditor confirms the error, they must correct it and credit the consumer's account. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) allows consumers to challenge unauthorized transactions and have their accounts recredited in case of errors, similar to the Fair Credit Billing Act. It establishes rights and responsibilities in electronic fund transfer systems. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) establishes rights, liabilities, and responsibilities for participants in electronic fund transfer systems. It limits a consumer's liability for unauthorized transfers if reported within two business days. Financial institutions must provide documentation of all electronic fund transfers initiated by the consumer. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) requires financial institutions to provide consumers with documentation of all electronic fund transfers initiated by the consumer. If a consumer believes there is an error in the documentation provided, they must notify the financial institution within 60 days. The institution must then investigate the alleged error and report the results to the consumer within 10 business days. The consumer must notify the financial institution of any errors in electronic fund transfer documentation within 60 days. The institution must investigate and report the results to the consumer within 10 business days. If an error is confirmed, it must be corrected within one day, and the consumer's account may be provisionally recredited. The financial institution may provisionally recredit the consumer's account for alleged errors pending investigation. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to combat identity theft and strengthen protection of personal information. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to crack down on criminals trafficking in stolen identities, protect personal information, assist law enforcement in prosecuting identity thieves, educate consumers and businesses on protection, and increase safeguards on personal data. The plan focuses on improving data security, making it harder for identity thieves to obtain consumer data, helping victims recover, and deterring theft through aggressive prosecution and punishment. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended closing gaps in federal criminal statutes to prosecute identity theft-related offenses more effectively. Recommendations include amending identity theft statutes to prosecute thieves targeting corporations, adding new crimes to aggravated identity theft offenses, and updating statutes on electronic theft. The recommendations from the President's Identity Theft Task Force include amending statutes to prosecute identity theft targeting corporations, adding new crimes to aggravated identity theft offenses, updating electronic theft laws, penalizing creators of malicious software, enhancing sentences for identity thieves affecting multiple victims, and implementing the REAL ID Act of 2005. The Real ID Act of 2005, implemented by the Department of Homeland Security, establishes standards for state-issued driver's licenses and identification cards to meet federal requirements. This includes incorporating specific information and security features, verifying the identity and legal status of applicants, and ensuring the source of documentation. The Real ID Act of 2005 sets standards for state-issued driver's licenses and identification cards, including security features, identity verification, and document source verification. States can request extensions until December 31, 2009, with the possibility of a second extension until May 10, 2011 for meeting security benchmarks. The Real ID Act of 2005 allows states to request extensions for compliance with security benchmarks until May 10, 2011. The rule mandates replacing non-compliant licenses with REAL ID cards by specific deadlines based on birth dates. Effective March 31, 2008.
